prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA because I want my hair fixed, for free, by the hairdresser?
[What I showed her](http://imgur.com/KmuiLRL)


[What I got](http://imgur.com/gEiWAi4)


I asked my stylist to do a light brown rose gold, and emphasized that I wanted it a light brown, warm color.

I showed her the picture more than a week in advance of the appointment so she had time to get any colors she didn’t have. 

I told her multiple times I wanted a light brown.  I know you can’t perfectly match the picture, but I think I made it obvious I wanted more brown than red in my hair.  I would have been fine without the rose tint.  My hair was bleach blonde to begin with.

She’s going to try to fix it but I don’t think I should have to pay, this is clearly not what I asked for.  Am I the asshole?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who wrote this is in the wrong. So the situation is about a hairdresser who messed up the color. The user showed a picture of what they wanted (light brown rose gold) and what they got (which seems redder). They emphasized wanting more brown than red, and their hair was already bleached blonde.

First, did the stylist make a mistake? The client provided a reference image and mentioned multiple times wanting a light brown with more brown than red. The result looks more red, which isn't what was agreed upon. The client is now refusing to pay for the fix. 

The key points here: The client gave clear instructions, provided a reference ahead of time, and the outcome didn't match. The stylist is responsible for adhering to the client's request. If the mistake was due to the stylist's error, then the client shouldn't have to pay for the correction. 

But wait, sometimes color can be tricky, especially with bleach blonde starting. Maybe the stylist had a good reason, like the color didn't exist and they had to use an alternative. But the client mentioned that the stylist had a week to get the color. If the stylist didn't have the right color and didn't communicate that, then the fault is on the stylist. 

Also, the client is not asking for a perfect match but a light brown, warm color. The result is more red, which is a significant deviation. The client's main point is that the work wasn't done as requested. In such cases, the salon is usually responsible for covering the cost of fixing their mistake. 

So the answer would be B (No, the author is not in the wrong) because the stylist didn't deliver the service as agreed. The client communicated their needs clearly and the result wasn't what was asked for. The client isn't at fault here.
